history:
***history***
female: (Frustration) You're the only one I know who loves his parents.
male: (Neutral) I know it went out of style didn't it?
female: (Neutral) It's okay.  It's a good thing.
female: (Neutral) You know it's lovely here.  The air is sweet.
male: (Frustration) You're not sorry you came.
female: (Frustration) Not sorry, no but I'm not staying.
male: (Frustration) Why?
female: (Frustration) In the first place, your mother as much as told me to go.
male: (Frustration) Well.
female: (Frustration) You saw that and you- you've been kind of-
male: (Anger) What?
female: (Frustration) Well kind of embarrassed ever since I got here.
male: (Frustration) The trouble is I planned on sneaking up on you over a period of a week or so but they take it for granted that we're all set.
female: (Frustration) I knew they would, your mother anyway.
male: (Frustration) How did you know?
female: (Frustration) From her point of view why else would I come?
male: (Frustration) Wouldn't you want to?
male: (Neutral) I guess you know this is why I asked you to come.
female: (Happiness) I guess this is why I came.
male: (Happiness) Ann, I love you.  I love you a great deal.  I love you.
male: (Happiness) I have no imagination that's all I know to tell you.
male: (Happiness) I'm embarrassing you.  I didn't want to tell it to you here.  I
male: (Excited) wanted some place we'd never been, a place where we'd be brand new to each other.
male: (Excited) You think this is wrong, this chair, this yard.  I want you to be ready for me.  I don't want to win you away from anything.
female: (Happiness) Chris, I've been ready a long, long time.
male: (Neutral) And he's gone forever.  You're sure?
female: (Neutral) I almost got married two years ago.
male: (Neutral) Why didn't you?
female: (Happiness) You started to write me.
male: (Neutral) You felt something that far back?
female: (Happiness) Every day since.
male: (Neutral) Ann, why didn't you let me know?
female: (Happiness) I was waiting for you, Chris.  Till then you never wrote and then when you did what did you say.  I mean you sure can be ambiguous you know.
male: (Happiness) Give me a kiss, Ann.  Give me a-God I kissed you.
male: (Happiness) I kissed Annie.  How long, how long I've been waiting to kiss you.
female: (Happiness) I'll never forgive you.  Why did you wait all these years?  All I've done is sit and wonder if I was crazy for thinking of you.
male: (Happiness) Annie, we're going to live now.  I'm going to make you so happy.
female: (Frustration) Not like that you're not.
male: (Frustration) I kissed you.
female: (Frustration) Like Larry's brother.  Do it like you, Chris.
female: (Frustration) What is it Chris?
male: (Frustration) Let's drive some place.  I want to be alone with you.
female: (Frustration) No.  What is it Chris, your mother?
male: (Sadness) No, nothing like that.
female: (Frustration) Well then what's wrong?  Even in your letters there was something ashamed.
male: (Sadness) Yes.  I suppose I have been but it's going from me.
female: (Frustration) You've got to tell me.
male: (Frustration) I don't know where to start.
female: (Frustration) It wouldn't work this way.
male: (Sadness) There's so many things mixed up.
male: (Sadness) You remember overseas I was in command of a company?
female: (Neutral) Yeah, sure.
male: (Sadness) Well I lost them.
female: (Sadness) How many?
male: (Sadness) Just about all.
female: (Frustration) Oh, gees.
male: (Sadness) It takes a lot of time to toss that off because they weren't just men.
male: (Sadness) For instance, one time it had been raining several days and this kid came to me and gave me his last pair of dry socks.
male: (Sadness) I put them in my pocket. that's only a little thing but these are the kind of guys I had.
male: (Sadness) They didn't die.  They killed themselves for each other.  I mean that exactly.  A little more selfish and they'd have been here today.
male: (Sadness) And I got this idea watching them go down.  Everything was being destroyed see, but it seemed to me that there was one new thing that was made
male: (Sadness) a sort of responsibility man for man.  You understand me?
male: (Sadness) And then I came home and it was amazing.
male: (Frustration) There was no meaning in it here.
male: (Frustration) The whole thing to them was sort of a bus accident. Then I went to work with father and that whole rat race again.
male: (Sadness) I felt, what you said, ashamed somehow
male: (Sadness) because nobody was changed at all.  It seemed to make suckers out of a lot of guys.
male: (Sadness) I felt wrong to be alive, to open the new bank book, to drive the new car, to see the new refrigerator.
male: (Frustration) I mean you can take those things out of war but
male: (Sadness) when you drive the new car, you have to know that it came out of the love a man can have for a man.  You've got to be a little better because of that.
male: (Sadness) Otherwise what you have is really just loot and there's blood on it.  I didn't want to take any of it.
male: (Sadness) I guess that included you.
female: (Neutral) And do you still feel that way?
male: (Neutral) I want you now, Annie.
female: (Anger) Because you mustn't feel that way anymore because you have a right to whatever you have, Chris, do you understand, everything
female: (Anger) that includes me.  And your money there's nothing wrong in your money.  Your father put hundreds of planes in the air.
Based on the conversation ***history*** above, as female, please choose the most appropriate emotion among {Frustration,Neutral,Anger,Other,Disgust,Excited,Sadness,Happiness,Surprise,Fear} to respond to the female
SourceData: You should be proud.  A man should be paid for that.
Coct: Oh, Chris, I've missed you too.
